questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with malodorous vaginal discharge and dysuria. The examination finding is shown below. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and image showing strawberry vagina and cervix are suggestive of trichomoniasis. The drug of choice is metronidazole. It is given as a single dose of 2g.

Both metronidazole and tinidazole are effective in the management of trichomonas vaginitis. Tinidazole has been reported to have fewer GI-related side effects and less resistance compared to metronidazole. However, it is much more expensive and is preferred in cases refractory to metronidazole.

questions.text: Metronidazole is selectively active against anaerobic and microaerophilic organisms because:

choices.text: Aerobes have oxygen gradient inside the cell which deactivates  metronidazole moiety
Only anaerobes and microaerophilic organisms reduce it to generate reactive nitro radicals
Aerobes have efflux drug pumping mechanism for metronidazole
Metronidazole inserts pore in the cell membrane of  anaerobes and microaerophilic bacteria

questions.solution:
Metronidazole is selectively active against anaerobic and microaerophilic organisms because only these organisms reduce it to generate reactive nitro radicals.

They contain electron transport components that donate an electron to metronidazole. This results in the formation of a highly reactive nitro radical anion that targets DNA and kills the organism.

questions.text: A child presents with diarrhea, weight loss, and abdominal pain. His mother reports stools to be greasy and foul-smelling. A wet preparation of the stool sample is shown below. What is first-line therapy for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the presence of cysts of Giardia lamblia in stool point towards a diagnosis of giardiasis, and tinidazole is the treatment of choice for this condition.

Both metronidazole and tinidazole are considered first-line drugs however, tinidazole is considered superior in its efficacy in comparison to metronidazole.

Drug dosage:

  • Metronidazole: 250- 500mg TID orally for 7 days
  • Tinidazole: 2g single dose orally

The cyst of Giardia is small and oval, and is surrounded by a hyaline cyst wall. Its internal structure includes two pairs of nuclei grouped at one end. A young cyst contains one pair of nuclei. The axostyle lies diagonally, forming a dividing line within the cyst wall.

questions.text: Metronidazole is least likely to be effective in the treatment of:
questions.solution:
Metronidazole is not effective in the management of pneumocystosis caused by Pneumocystis jirovecii. Co-trimoxazole is used in the management of this condition.

Metronidazole is used in the following conditions:

  • Giardiasis
  • Trichomoniasis
  • Amoebiasis
  • Bacterial vaginosis
  • Anaerobic infections - bacteroides and clostridium.
  • Pseudomembranous colitis (alternative to vancomycin & fidaxomicin)

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with lower abdominal pain and diarrhea. The stool examination finding is shown below. Which of the following drugs cannot be used for the eradication of intestinal cysts in this condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows hematophagous trophozoite of Entamoeba histolytica and metronidazole is not an effective agent against cysts of amoeba in the colon.

Metronidazole is used in the treatment of amoebiasis (amoebic colitis, amoebic liver abscess). It is well absorbed from the small intestine and only a small amount of the unabsorbed drug reaches the colon, which is insufficient to kill the cysts.

Hence, luminal agents like diloxanide furoate, nitazoxanide or iodoquinol are required for the eradication of cysts and trophozoites in the intestine.

questions.text: Which of the following is used in the treatment of a patient with asymptomatic intestinal amoebiasis?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for the treatment of asymptomatic intestinal luminal amoebiasis due to E. histolytica is paromomycin.

Paromomycin (aminosidine) is an aminoglycoside that has poor oral absorption and hence it acts only in the intestinal lumen as a luminal amebicide. It has no effect against extraintestinal organisms.

questions.text: A 21-year-old male presented to the OPD complaining of blood-streaked stools. Sigmoidoscopy was done and it showed ulcers in the sigmoid. Biopsy was taken from this area and the histopathological image is given below.  Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the histopathological image showing flask-shaped ulcers are suggestive of intestinal amoebiasis. The most appropriate treatment is intravenous metronidazole.

The amoebic ulcer which is flask-shaped is the typical lesion seen in intestinal amoebiasis. The ulcers are multiple and are confined to the colon. Sometimes, in secondary intestinal lesions, the ulcers are numerous in the cecum, followed by the sigmoido-rectal region.

Three classes of drugs are used in the treatment of amebiasis:

  • Luminal amoebicides- diloxanide furoate, iodoquinol, paromomycin, and tetracycline. They act in the intestinal lumen but not in tissues.
  • Tissue amoebicides- emetine and chloroquine. They are effective in systemic infection but less effective in the intestine.
  • Both luminal and tissue amebicides- Metronidazole, tinidazole and imidazole. They act on both sites and are the drug of choice for treating amebic colitis and amebic liver abscess.

questions.text: A patient presents with sudden onset fever with chills and malaise. On examination splenomegaly was present. Bone marrow picture is shown in the image. Which of the following drugs is not used in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the bone marrow picture showing macrophages infected with intracellular Leishman-Donovan bodies point towards a diagnosis of visceral leishmaniasis. Hydroxychloroquine is not indicated in the treatment of this condition.

The drugs effective in visceral leishmaniasis are: 

  • Liposomal amphotericin B (preferred)
  • Sodium stibogluconate (not in India)
  • Miltefosine
  • Paromomycin
  • Pentamidine (rarely used)

Hydroxychloroquine is an antimalarial agent and is also used in the treatment of dermatological conditions like: 

  • Cutaneous lupus erythematosus
  • Cutaneous dermatomyositis
  • Polymorphous light eruption
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda
  • Sarcoidosis

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with the finding as shown in the image. She gives history of travel to South America and was bitten by a reduvid bug. Which of the following is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The scenario and the image showing Romaña sign point towards a diagnosis of Chagas disease (American trypanosomiasis) and the drug of choice in this condition is benznidazole. 

American trypanosomiasis is caused by Trypanosoma cruzi and can be managed by either benznidazole or nifurtimox. Due to its favorable safety profile, benznidazole is considered the drug of choice.

Romaña sign is the unilateral painless periorbital swelling associated with the acute stage of Chagas disease.

Albendazole and metronidazole are not indicated for American trypanosomiasis. Albendazole is used in infections with Ascaris lumbricoides, Trichuris trichiura and hookworms. Metronidazole is used in the treatment of trichomoniasis and amebiasis.

questions.text: A patient presents in the late stage of West African sleeping sickness. What is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
Nifurtimox in combination with eflornithine is the drug of choice for late-stage West African sleeping sickness. It is caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambiense.

Nifurtimox alone is indicated in American trypanosomiasis. 

Melarsoprol is the drug of choice for late-stage East African (Rhodesian) trypanosomiasis. It is not indicated in combination with nifurtimox.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs can be used as first-line treatment in patients with early-stage of East African trypanosomiasis?
questions.solution:
Suramin is the first-line therapy for early-stage East African trypanosomiasis caused by Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense.

It is also active against Trypanosoma brucei gambiense but only indicated as a second-line agent when pentamidine fails or is contraindicated. 

Melarsoprol is the only effective drug available for the treatment of the late encephalopathic stage of East African sleeping sickness. It is caused by Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense. Melarsoprol is effective in earlier stages also but is avoided because of its toxicity.

questions.text: The microscopy of fecal sample of a patient showed presence of Ascaris lumbricoides eggs. This condition can most effectively be treated with which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Roundworm infestation is most effectively treated with albendazole. It is considered as the drug of choice for the treatment of roundworm (Ascaris lumbricoides) infestation. 

Albendazole is considered as the drug of choice for treatment of infestation by:

  • Whipworm - Trichuris trichura causing trichuriasis
  • Hookworm - Ancylostoma duodenale
  • Roundworm - Ascaris lumbricoides
  • Dog tapeworm - Echinococcus granulosus causing hydatid disease

Albendazole is administered as a single oral 400-mg dose to adults and children more than 2 years of age. Safety is not established for children less than 2 years. However, according to WHO, if the benefit outweighs the risk, albendazole at 200 mg can be given to children between the ages of 1-2years.

questions.text: What is the primary mechanism of action of benzimidazole?
questions.solution:
The primary mechanism of action of benzimidazoles is by inhibition of microtubule polymerization. Benzimidazoles bind to beta-tubulin and cause inhibition of microtubule polymerization.

Drugs belonging to the benzimidazole group are:

  • Albendazole
  • Mebendazole
  • Triclabendazole
  • Thiabendazole.

Mechanisms of action: 

  • Inhibition of mitochondrial fumarate reductase
  • Reduced glucose transport
  • Uncoupling of oxidative phosphorylation

questions.text: A young man working at a dairy farm presents with fever and abdominal pain. Examination of his stool samples revealed the finding shown in the image. Which of the following benzimidazoles is indicated in this condition?
questions.solution: The given image showing operculated egg (egg having a lid-like structure on its end) is suggestive of Fasciola hepatica and the benzimidazole indicated for infection with this organism is triclabendazole.

questions.text: The MRI of a patient who presented with new-onset seizures is shown below. What is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
The MRI findings (multiple cysticerci within the brain) are suggestive of neurocysticercosis and albendazole is the drug of choice in this condition.

Glucocorticoid therapy is usually begun before initiating albendazole and continued for several days after the commencement of therapy. It reduces the inflammatory reaction to the dead and dying cysticerci of Taenia solium.

Note: Even though Albendazole and Praziquantel are used as a combination, the single best answer choice to this question is Albendazole.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man hospitalized with a hydatid cyst refused to undergo surgical removal of the cyst. He was treated with high dose albendazole for 3 months. This patient should be monitored for toxicity to the:
questions.solution:
The patient described above should be monitored for toxicity to the liver. Liver dysfunction is one of the common adverse effects of albendazole therapy and liver function tests should be routinely conducted when long-term therapy is initiated.

Long-term albendazole therapy is also associated with bone marrow toxicity. Therefore, blood counts should also be regularly monitored.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice in patients with onchocerciasis?
questions.solution:
Ivermectin is the drug of choice for onchocerciasis caused by Oncocerca volvulus in adults and children aged more than 5 years. 

Ivermectin is the drug of choice for: 

  • Strongyloidiasis
  • Onchocerciasis

It is associated with Mazzotti reaction (fever, pruritic rash, lymphadenopathy) as a side effect when given for filariasis due to immune system activation by the dying parasite. This reaction is also seen with the use of diethylcarbamazine.

Related Pearl: Indications of Ivermectin

  • Onchocerciasis
  • Chemoprophylaxis of filariasis
  • Strongyloidiasis
  • Gnathostomiasis
  • Scabies
  • Head lice

questions.text: A patient presents with itchy, serpiginous eruptions as shown in the image. He says that these lesions advance rapidly to different sites. What is the primary mechanism of action of the drug preferred for this disease?

choices.text: Activation of glutamate gated chloride channels
Inhibition of glutamate gated chloride channels

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image showing larva currens, points towards a diagnosis of strongyloidiasis, and the drug of choice in this condition is ivermectin. The mechanism of action of ivermectin primarily involves activation of glutamate-gated chloride channels found only in invertebrates. 

Ivermectin activates glutamate-activated chloride channels in the nerves and muscles of nematode and results in the influx of chloride into the cell. This causes hyperpolarization of cells and results in paralysis of nematodes.

questions.text: What is the first-line treatment for a patient presenting with the finding shown below?
questions.solution:
The above image shows cutaneous larva migrans. Ivermectin is the first-line drug for the treatment of cutaneous larva migrans.

The first-line drugs used in cutaneous larva migrans include:

  • Ivermectin - 200μg/kg orally single dose
  • Albendazole - 400mg orally for 3 days

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents with painless hematuria. He has a history of travel to Kenya. Urine microscopy revealed the finding shown below. What is the drug of choice in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the image showing the egg of Schistosoma hematobium (egg with terminal spine), point towards the diagnosis of schistosomiasis. Praziquantel is the drug of choice for schistosomiasis caused by all Schistosoma species that can infect humans.

A single oral dose of 40 mg/kg or three doses of 20 mg/kg each, given 4–6 h apart, generally produce cure rates of 70%–95% and consistently high reductions (>85%) in egg counts.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs causes flaccid paralysis of Ascaris lumbricoides?
questions.solution:
Piperazine causes flaccid paralysis of Ascaris lumbricoides.

It acts as a GABA receptor agonist and increases chloride ion conductance across the Ascaris muscle membrane. This results in hyperpolarisation and reduced excitability, which leads to muscle relaxation and flaccid paralysis.

Metrifonate, levamisole and tribendimidine are anthelminthic drugs that cause spastic paralysis.

questions.text: Diethylcarbamazine is used for the treatment of:
questions.solution:
Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) is used for the control and treatment of lymphatic filariasis caused by W. bancrofti, B. malayi and B. timori.

Other indications for the use of DEC are:

  • Loiasis
  • Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, fatigue, and malaise. Investigations reveal anemia and thrombocytopenia. Thin blood smear is shown below. What is the recommended therapy for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and the microscopic image showing tetrads or Maltese cross, point towards a diagnosis of babesiosis and the recommended therapy for this condition is azithromycin plus atovaquone.

Babesiosis is a zoonotic infection that resembles malaria. It presents with febrile illness, hemolysis and hemoglobinuria.

For mild or moderate disease: Azithromycin plus atovaquone.

For severe disease:

  • Recommended regimen - azithromycin plus atovaquone.
  • Alternative regimen - clindamycin plus quinine.

Severe babesiosis typically occurs in patients with one or more of the following characteristics: age >50 years, neonatal prematurity, asplenia/hyposplenism, HIV/AIDS, malignancy, and immunosuppressive therapy.

questions.text: A  patient presented with fever and cervical lymphadenopathy. Investigations revealed IgM toxoplasma antibodies. Which of the following agents is most effective in treating this condition?
questions.solution:
Pyrimethamine is the most effective agent against toxoplasmosis and is present in most of the regimens. It is combined with sulfadiazine or clindamycin for toxoplasmosis.

Trimethoprim plus sulfamethoxazole (cotrimoxazole) is an alternative.
